titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Nelson C. Davis Papers FA048

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-01 00:21:24 -0400.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material in this collection has been arranged in three series:

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Nelson Caryl Davis was born in Osceola, Nebraska, on August 26, 1892, the posthumous son of John E. Davis. His mother remarried and moved to Ceres, California, in 1896, where young Davis attended local public schools. After graduating from high school, he entered the Hospital Corps of the United States Army and spent two years (1910-1912) in the Philippine Islands. While in the armed forces, his interest turned toward the study of tropical diseases, which was to constitute his life's work. Between 1914 and 1917 he completed undergraduate work at The University of California at Berkeley, and immediately entered medical studies at The University of California Medical School.

On January 12, 1917, he married Mary Faye Caulkins of Ceres, California, then also a student at The University of California at Berkeley. This marriage was to produce five sons, one of whom died in infancy (1923) during Dr. Davis's first period of service in Brazil.

After a short period of inactive military service during World War I, Dr. Davis received a Hooper Foundation fellowship in medical research (1918) and did studies of liver pathology with Dr. George H. Whipple. This research resulted in his first published articles. He also briefly served as an assistant in the Department of Pathology at The University of California before receiving his M.D. in 1921.

In May 1922, Dr. Davis became a regular member of the staff of the International Health Board of The Rockefeller Foundation. His appointment as Junior Field Director carried him to Porto Alegre, Brazil where he participated in hookworm control and related programs. He was reassigned to malaria work in Argentina, where he was stationed intermittently from July 1925 to July 1927. This assignment increased his interest in medical entomology, and he continued to produce articles on anopheline mosquitoes and malaria for the rest of his life.

Upon returning to the United States on leave in the summer of 1927, he attended courses at The School of Hygiene and Public Health of The Johns Hopkins University. After a brief supplementary period of study (March-May 1931), he was awarded the degree of Doctor of Public Health from that institution.

At the end of his first study leave (July 1928), Dr. Davis undertook the establishment of a laboratory at Bahia, Brazil, to carry on yellow fever research in South America and also to conduct laboratory studies for the yellow fever control service maintained jointly by the Government of Brazil and The Rockefeller Foundation. Through his research it was established that yellow fever was transmitted by several species of mosquitoes other than Aedes aegypti, the previously recognized agent of infection. His collaborators in this work included Drs. Martin Frobisher, Jr., Raymond C. Shannon, J. Austin Kerr, and Henry W. Kumm. Dr. Paul A. Lewis, one of his early coworkers at the Bahia laboratory, died of yellow fever early in 1929 - one of the noted martyrs to that disease. Dr. Davis contracted it at the same time, but survived.

Complications arising from this bout with yellow fever led to Dr. Davis's own death four years later. During his second period of study at Johns Hopkins (1931), his gall bladder had been removed. Although in steady pain, he continued his heavy load of research and leadership of the Bahia laboratory until his sudden death on October 20, 1933, from acute edema.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Nelson C. Davis Collection will be of interest both to the historian of medical research and of medical education. The lecture notes and class papers prepared by Dr. Davis at all levels of his training have been preserved in this collection. Also included are drafts of papers, some of them unpublished, at various stages of preparation, reprints of his published articles, and a wide variety of supporting research materials (such as reprints and periodicals), many taken from Portuguese- or Spanish-language publications. A substantial portion of his laboratory diary (kept at Bahia from 1928 to 1933) can be found in this collection as well as a number of field notebooks and records of experiments. Personal correspondence, however, has been rather scantily preserved.

Significant correspondents in this collection include Mark F. Boyd, Rollin C. Dean, John H. Janney, Robert H. Kirk, Henry W. Kumm, E. R. Rickard, Francis M. Root, F. F. Russell, Wilbur A. Sawyer, Fred L. Soper, and George K. Strode.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: A complete transcript of the laboratory duties and of much of the field notes kept by Dr. Davis at the Bahia laboratory can be found in the archives of The Rockefeller Foundation (Record Group 1.1, Series 305.O). Correspondence with Rockefeller Foundation officials -- especially F. F. Russell and Fred L. Soper -- may also be found in the Foundation archives (Record Group 1.1, Series 305.O and 305.I). Also available are a large number of photographs relating to the work of the Bahia laboratory contemporaneous with Dr. Davis's period of service there -- many of which originally accompanied his reports to the Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Processing was completed as of April 27, 1978.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of Nelson C. Davis were deposited with The Rockefeller Foundation Archives by his son, Franklin Davis, on December 6, 1971.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries 1 - Correspondence Subseries 2 - Financial Material Subseries 3 - Class Notes and Papers Subseries 4 - Articles Subseries 5 - Plates and Drawings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material contained in this series consists of documents generated by Dr. Davis as a private person or in the course of his training and research. Included in this series are correspondence, financial material, class notes and papers, and scientific articles in various stages of development (from manuscript to reprint). Papers of his wife, Mrs. Mary Faye Davis, or his sons Donald and Irvine, have also been included in Subseries 1 and 3.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Material in this subseries has been filed chronologically; incoming and outgoing correspondence have not been filed together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of handwritten or typed letters to Dr. Davis with carbon copies of his replies. The bulk of this correspondence is not of a personal nature, but is rather in the nature of scientific inquiries or reports on activities. A few letters to and from Dr. Davis's sons, Donald and Irvine Davis, have been included as part of the regular correspondence; other of their papers not in the nature of correspondence have been included separately at the end of this subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Drawings and class papers by Donald and Irvine Davis.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material in this subseries has been arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists mainly of income tax returns, insurance vouchers, receipts, bank statements, and records of purchase.

did.unittitle: Personal Papers - Class Notes and Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material in this subseries has been arranged chronologically and then alphabetically by course title; since much of it can be dated by internal evidence only, this order must be regarded as approximate for the whole.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of lecture and laboratory notebooks, class papers, course syllabi, and other classroom material used by Dr. Davis.

Dr. Davis's undergraduate training took place at The University of California at Berkeley (1914-1917); he received his M.D. from The University of California Medical School in 1921. His further education at The Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health (1927-1928, 1931) earned him the degree of Doctor of Public Health.
Class notes and papers by Mrs. Mary Faye Davis have been filed at the end of this subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials in this subseries are arranged chronologically based on date of publication, followed by completed articles left unpublished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of manuscript and typescript drafts or copies of studies by Dr. Davis on various entomological or medical topics. Dr. Davis's dissertation for The Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health ("Studies upon 'Aedes aegypti' at Various Temperatures," May 1931) is included here, as it remained unpublished as a whole, although two articles were later derived from it. This subseries closes with copies of Dr. Davis's articles in reprint form.
The following articles are not represented in this collection:
1919 Davis, N.C. and Whipple, G.H. - The influence of fasting and various diets on the liver injury effected by chloroform anesthesia. Archives of Internal Medicine, 23:612-635, 1919.
Davis, N.C. and Whipple, G.H. - The influence of drugs and chemical agents on the liver necrosis of chloroform anaesthesia. Paper II. Archives of Internal Medicine, 23:636-654, 1919.

Davis, N.C., Hall, C.C. and Whipple, G.H. - The rapid construction of liver cell protein in a strict carbohydrate diet contrasted with fasting; mechanism of protein sparing action of carbohydrate. Archives of Internal Medicine, 23:689-710, 1919.

Davis, N.C. and Whipple, G.H. - Liver regeneration following chloroform injury as influenced by various diets; mechanism of protein sparing action of fat. Archives of Internal Medicine, 23:711-722, 1919.
1930 Shannon, R.C. and Davis, N.C. - Observations on the anophelini (culicidae) of Bahia, Brazil. Annals of the Entomological Society of America, 23:467-505, No. 3, September.
1933 Notes on some South American mosquitoes. II. The genus 'Mansonia', subgenus 'Rhynchotaonia'. Annals of the Entomological Society of America, Columbus. 26:619-639. December 1933.
Transmission of yellow fever virus by 'Colux Fatigens' Weidemann. Annals of the Entomological Soc. of America, Columbus. 26:491-495. September 1933.
The survival of yellow fever virus in ticks. American Journal of Tropical Medicine, Baltimore. 13:547-554. November 1933.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of a single undated folder of engraved plates and drawings of biological subjects made by Dr. Davis.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries 1 - Porto Alegre, Brazil Subseries 2 - Field Notebooks Subseries 3 - Bahia, Brazil Subseries 4 - Reports Subseries 5 - Articles Subseries 6 - Monthly Bulletins Subseries 7 - File Card Bibliography

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this series consists of documents related to service assignments undertaken by Dr. Davis with The Rockefeller Foundation. It includes monthly reports, some correspondence, maps of areas visited, examination charts, diaries, field note books, and an expense book.

Dr. Davis's foreign service falls into two main divisions - the first (1922-1927) spent mainly in Brazil, where he engaged in hookworm and malaria control work; the second (1928-1933) as director of the Yellow Fever Laboratory in Bahia, Brazil. With the exception of some time spent in Argentina (July-December 1925 and January-July 1927), his activities are amply documented by the material in this series. Further correspondence is available in the Rockefeller Foundation Archives, Record Group 1.1, Series 305.I and 305.O.

The laboratory diaries for the Yellow Fever Laboratory at Bahia originally consisted of seven bound and numbered handwritten volumes; of these, volume IV (February-October 1931) is missing. This volume was kept by Dr. Martin Frobisher, Jr., in the absence of Dr. Davis. A complete typescript of these diaries, including the missing volume, together with typescripts of some of Dr. Davis's field note books, may be found in the Rockefeller Foundation Archives, Record Group 1.1, Series 305.O.

This series continues with typescript reports or articles sent to Dr. Davis for comment or information by officers of The Rockefeller Foundation, and concludes with copies of The International Health Board's newspaper in Brazil ("O Telescopio" - later, "O Saneamento").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of reports, charts, graphs, examination records, an expense book, and field note books kept during Dr. Davis's first period of service in South America, spent primarily in Porto Alegre and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Maps and Charts, Experiment Records

arrangement.p: Subseries 1 - Reprints by Rockefeller Foundation Personnel Subseries 2 - Reprints by Non-Rockefeller Foundation Individuals Subseries 3 - Monographs Subseries 4 - Periodicals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this series consists of reprints, monographs, and periodicals--mostly on medical topics related to Dr. Davis's work in hookworm, malaria, and yellow fever. It was gathered primarily as background material for his own research.
